weibull++
Seven Basic Tools That Can Improve Quality

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Ashweni Sahni
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The presentation of the seven tools in the framework of FDA's QRS.

X.T: Kano Model Analysis
Kano Model Analysis

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good overview.

X.T: Kano Analysis: A Little Something Extra Can Have Big Results

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Kathy Parker
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good presentation of the Kano theory, but they have forgotten to indicate that "delighters" becomes "performers" then "musts" as the market matures.

X.T: Basics of HALT, HASS and HAST
X.ST: highly accelerated life test, stress screening and stress testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good presentation of HALT and HASS for electronic products.

X.T: Auditors, Turtle Diagrams and Waste

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mike Micklewright
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Quality systems should not get fatter to please auditors.

X.T: I'm Excited About ISO 9001:2008!
X.ST: I was also excited for my 40th birthday

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mike Micklewright
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The new release of ISO 9001 contains only minor changes.If the standard does not evolve, this may be its downfall.

X.T: Do We Have To?

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Denise Robitaille
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some companies need to be taught the interest and the ROI of each ISO 9001 requirement.

X.T: Why Root-Cause Analysis Sucks in the United States

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mike Micklewright
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Micklewright lists some reasons why root analysis is not properly done.

X.T: The Careless Ones

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Robert C. Martin
ARTICLE.COMMENT: When companies care more about their schedule than about their customers...

X.T: Using SW-TMM to Improve the Testing Process

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Thomas C. Staab
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the TMM levels and some advice to perform a maturity assessment.

X.T: Failure Modes & Effects Analysis
Failure Modes & Effects Analysis

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good presentation of the FMEA tool.

X.T: A Development of Hazard Analysis to aid Software Design
A Development of Hazard Analysis to aid Software Design

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: J. A. McDermid
D. J. Pumfrey
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors start to build a hazard analysis methodology for software by analogy to the HAZOP system used for chemical plants. The proposed methodology is simple (probably too simple...) and should help to find some failure conditions. But I think it is usable mainly for embedded control/detector systems.

X.T: Failure Mode And Effects Analysis of Software-Based Automation Systems
Failure Mode And Effects Analysis of Software-Based Automation Systems
Failure Mode And Effects Analysis of Software-Based Automation Systems

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Haapanen Pentti
Helminen Atte
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A thorough analysis of the literature about FMEA for software.

X.T: Experience Report: Contributions of SFMEA to Requirements Analysis
Experience Report: Contributions of SFMEA to Requirements Analysis

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Robyn R. Lutz
Robert M. Woodhouse
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors give a clear description of how they used, first, forward searching (SFMEA) to identify the defect causes and, then, a backward analysis to examine the possibility of the causes.

X.T: Improving Hazard Classification through the Reuse of Descriptive Arguments
Improving Hazard Classification through the Reuse of Descriptive Arguments

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Shamus P. Smith
Michael D. Harrison
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors describe how they start to methodologically reuse arguments mitigating a risk to other risks.

X.T: Using Fault Tree Analysis to Improve Software Testing

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Anand Paropkari
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic introduction to Fault Tree Analysis for people having to test software.

X.T: Using the GROW model for solving problems

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Bob Griffiths
ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the GROW model.

BLIST.TITLE: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks

X.T: Dogma and Definition
Dogma and Definition

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Six Sigma is used too broadly to fulfil what people expect from it, the author proposes here to limit its definition and scope.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #10
Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #10 - Conflating systems, strategies and tools

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: When people define their quality policy by the tools instead of by its strategy.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #9
Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #9

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Continuous improvement is anybody's job in the company, Black Belts should focus on breakthrough.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #8
Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #8

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Before optimizing a process, its real profit shall be evaluated.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #7
Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #7

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Six Sigma is not only a matter of having some BBs, the company must provide a supporting infrastructure.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #6
X.ST: Constraining your improvement activities to manufacturing processes

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #6
X.ST: Constraining your improvement activities to manufacturing processes

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Six Sigma is not only for manufacturing.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #5

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: BBs and MBBs must really know about statistics theory to properly use them.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #4
Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #4

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: If a problem has a well known solution, use it instead of trying to use DMAIC.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #3
Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #3

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some other statistic traps that can be avoided only if BBs and MBBs really understand what they are computing.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #2
Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #2

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Steven dives further in the ideas already exposed in #9: Six Sigma deals with the big problems, but the daily management deals with the small ones, resulting in small incremental improvements.

X.T: Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #1
Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #1

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A company needs a strategic plan to ensure that Six Projects are aligned with the company objectives. Steven gives a short overview of a process to define such a plan.

X.T: Sick Sigma - Question authority and you'll win.

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Anthony D. Burns
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A nice little critic of Six Sigma, in particular on the 1.5 difference between Z long term and Z short term.

X.T: Sick Sigma, Part 2 - The tail wagging its dog

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Anthony D. Burns
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The critic on the 1.5 Z shift goes on...

X.T: Six Sigma Meets Software Development

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Maneesh Aggarwal
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author says that Six Sigma will improve software lifecycles. The article is not very interesting by itself, but the rebuttal and the discussion are worth reading.

X.T: Six Sigma and CRF Pages

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Suz Redfearn
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Covance used Six Sigma to reduce the number of missing CRF pages.

X.T: Six Sigma and the Corner Office

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT:
This is the same information as in Top Ten Stupid Six Sigma Tricks - #1The end is herehttp://www.six-sigma-online.com/index.php?view=article&id=12
enHTML: Six Sigma project must be aligned with the business's objectives.

X.T: Will Google Earn a Black Belt?

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Steven Ouellette
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Analysing huge amount of data, as Google is doing, will not be sufficient to find the solutions to the problems, some intelligence is required.

X.T: The Greatest Waste

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mike Micklewright
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The author estimates that 50% of work hours are lost by not working usefully.

X.T: Always Fix Broken Windows

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Peter Antman
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Enforcing a "Fix Next Sprint" policy to avoid a rotting code base.

X.T: Set the Tone With Project Setup

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Mike Jansen
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The first impressions of a newcomer will impact what he will deliver on the project, so Mike Jansen suggests to have a clean project setup, successful tests, clear log files, and organized dependencies.

X.T: The Importance of Excel

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Kwak
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Financial companies are relying too much on untested Excel sheets.

X.T: Software Peer Reviews: An Executive Overview with Karl Wiegers

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Karl Wiegers
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A good old-fashioned presentation of reviews: what can be reviewed, the different types of reviews, the advantages of reviews...

X.T: An Introductory Overview of ITIL® V3

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
An introduction to ITIL v2 provided by itSMFhttp://www.itsmfusa.org
enHTML.

X.T: Top Four Activities to Prepare for ISO 13485 Certification

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Jardine
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Very basic stuff: create a quality manual, find the compliance gaps, and define plans to fix them. I suspect this is simply an advertisement for MasterControl.

X.T: History's Worst Software Bugs

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Simson Garfinkel
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A top 10 of the most damaging bugs.

X.T: ARIANE 5 - Flight 501 Failure

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: the Inquiry Board
ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is the analysis of the first Ariane 5 flight failure and some resulting recommendations.

X.T: The trouble with Rover is revealed

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Ron Wilson
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the bug and fix of Mars rover Spirit.

X.T: Space Station: Internal NASA Reports Explain Origins of June Computer Crisis

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Oberg
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The triply redundant computers of IIS failed because of condensation.

X.T: An Investigation of the Therac-25 Accidents

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Nancy Leveson
Clark S. Turner
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed analysis of the mistakes that killed five persons by massive overdose.

X.T: Healthcare.gov and the Tyranny of the Innocents

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: James Bach
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The project was directed by people who had no clue on software project management.

X.T: We Did Nothing Wrong - Panama's Cancer Institute | A Dissection

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Debbie Gage
John McCormick
ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the Panama Multidata's bug: 21 patients died by gamma rays overdose.

X.T: FDA Statement on Radiation Overexposures in Panama

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The FDA statement on the Panama affair.

X.T: Panama Technicians Found Guilty

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: John McCormick
Tom Steinert-Threlkeld
ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: American Airlines' Fiasco
X.ST: An inevitable result of its attitude toward quality

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: William A. Levinson
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some discussion about American Airlines holding passengers eight hours in a parked airplane.

X.T: Starbucks’ Lean Ruins the Experience
X.ST: I want a caffeine rush, not to be in a rush

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Raissa Carey
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Applying blindly lean to user relationship results in a bad user experience.

X.T: The Ritz-Carlton Mystique
X.ST: Why the best is the best

ARTICLE.AUTHOR: Bill Kalmar
ARTICLE.COMMENT: Kalmar explains why Ritz-Carlton has reached such a good reputation, but he gives a very nice high level overview (as usual with this type of article), without reporting negative points or the day-to-day effects of the quality policy.
